Object code


Relocation bits


Names and locations of all external symbols defined in the object module

$S  \alpha \rightarrow bd b\mid b$

subject: Compiler Design
question:
Suppose we have a computer with single register and only three instructions given below:
$$\begin{array}{ll} \text{LOAD addren}  &  \text{; load register} \\ \text{} & \text{; from addren}\\ \text{STORE addren} & \text{; store register}\\ \text{} & \text{; at addren}\\ \text{ADD addren} & \text{; add register to}\\  \text{} & \text{; contents of addren}\\  \text{} & \text{; and place the result}\\    \text{} & \text{; in the register}\\  \end{array}$$
Consider the following grammar:

$A \rightarrow id : =E$
$E \rightarrow E+T\mid T$
$T \rightarrow (E)\mid id$
options: Write a syntax directed translation to generate code using this grammar for the computer described above.

subject: Compiler Design
question: A grammar $G$ is in Chomsky-Normal Form (CNF) if all its productions are of the form $A \to BC$ or $A \to a$, where $A,B$ and $C$, are non-terminals and $a$ is a terminal. Suppose $G$ is a CFG in CNF and $w$ is a string in $L(G)$ of length $n$, then how long is a derivation of $w$ in $G$?

options: Coroutine is just another name for a subroutine.

Syntax of if-then-else statements


Syntax of recursive procedures


Whether a variable has been declared before its use

b = 10
c = 20 
d = a + b
e = c + d 
f = c + e 
b = c + e 
e = b + f 
d = 5 + e
return d + f

If a procedure $P$ has two parameters as described in procedure definition:

procedure P (var x :integer; y: integer);
and if $P$ is called by ; $P(a, b)$
State precisely in a sentence what is pushed on stack for parameters $a$ and $b$
options: In the generated code for the body of procedure $P$, how will the addressing of formal parameters $x$ and $y$ differ?

It allocates space for the literals.


It computes the total length of the program.


It builds the symbol table for the symbols and their values.


It generates code for all the load and store register instructions.

subject: Compiler Design
question: The language $L,$ defined by the following grammar, allows use of real or integer data in expressions and assignment statements.
options: It is required to convert expression and assignment string of $L$ into postfix strings that use the type-specific operations $(+,i),(+,r),(*,i),(*,r),(:=,i)$ and $(:=,r)$

Write a syntax-directed translation scheme to convert expression and assignment strings into the postfix form. You may assume that the name and type of variable can be obtained by making the function calls’ give_name $(id)$ and give_type $(id)$ respectively.

subject: Compiler Design
question:
Consider the grammar

$S \rightarrow bSe$
$S \rightarrow PQR$
$P \rightarrow bPc$
$P \rightarrow  \varepsilon$
$Q \rightarrow cQd$
$Q \rightarrow  \varepsilon$
$R \rightarrow dRe$
$R \rightarrow \varepsilon$

where $S, P, Q, R$ are non-terminal symbols with $S$ being the start symbol; $b, c, d, e$ are terminal symbols and ‘$\varepsilon$’ is the empty string. This grammar generates strings of the form $b^i, c^j, d^k, e^m$ for some $i, j, k, m \geq 0$.


What is the condition on the values of $i, j, k, m$?
options: Find the smallest string that has two parse trees.

that support recursion


that support dynamic data structure

options: test a condition during the execution of the expanded program
to expand certain model statements depending upon the value of a condition during the execution of the expanded program
to expand certain model statements depending upon the value of a condition during the process of macro expansion

subject: Compiler Design
question: A language $L$ allows declaration of arrays whose sizes are not known during compilation. It is required to make efficient use of memory. Which one of the following is true?
options: A compiler using static memory allocation can be written for $L$
A compiler cannot be written for $L$; an interpreter must be used
A compiler using dynamic memory allocation can be written for $L$

$X ::= X \oplus Y \mid Y$
$Y::= Z * Y \mid Z$
$Z::= id $

Which of the following is true?
options: $\text{‘}\oplus\text{’}$ is left associative while $\text{‘}*\text{’}$ is right associative
$\text{‘}\oplus\text{’}$ is right associative while $\text{‘}*\text{’}$ is left associative

subject: Compiler Design
question: For the grammar below, a partial $LL(1)$ parsing table is also presented along with the grammar. Entries that need to be filled are indicated as $E1, E2,$ and $E3$. $\varepsilon$ is the empty string, \$ indicates end of input, and, $\mid$ separates alternate right hand sides of productions.$ S\rightarrow a A b B \mid b A a B \mid \varepsilon $$ A\rightarrow S $$ B\rightarrow S $$$\begin{array}{|l|l|}\hline \text{}  &  \textbf{a} & \textbf{b}  &  \textbf{\$} \\\hline  \text{$S$} & \text{E1} &  \text{E2}  &  \text{$S\rightarrow \varepsilon $} \\\hline  \text{$A$} & \text{$A\rightarrow S$} &  \text{$A\rightarrow S$}  &  \text{error} \\\hline  \text{$B$} & \text{$B\rightarrow S$} & \text{$B\rightarrow S$}  &  \text{$E3$} \\\hline \end{array}$$The FIRST and FOLLOW sets for the non-terminals $A$ and $B$ are$ \text{FIRST}(A) = \{a, b, \varepsilon\} =\text{FIRST}(B) $$ \text{FOLLOW}(A) = \{a, b\} $$ \text{FOLLOW}(B) = \{a, b, \$\} $ $ \text{FIRST}(A) = \{a, b, \$\} $$ \text{FIRST}(B) = \{a, b, \varepsilon\} $$ \text{FOLLOW}(A) = \{a, b\} $$ \text{FOLLOW}(B) = \{\$\} $ $ \text{FIRST}(A) = \{a, b, \varepsilon\} =\text{FIRST}(B) $$ \text{FOLLOW}(A) =\{a, b\} $$ \text{FOLLOW}(B) = \varnothing $ $ \text{FIRST}(A) = \{a, b\} = \text{FIRST}(B) $$ \text{FOLLOW}(A) = \{a, b\} $$ \text{FOLLOW}(B) =\{a, b\} $

question: Consider evaluating the following expression tree on a machine with load-store architecture in which memory can be accessed only through load and store instructions. The variables $a, b, c, d,$ and $e$ are initially stored in memory. The binary operators used in this expression tree can be evaluated by the machine only when operands are in registers. The instructions produce result only in a register. If no intermediate results can be stored in memory, what is the minimum number of registers needed to evaluate this expression?

Which one of the following represents the parse tree for expression $(7 \downarrow 3 \uparrow 4 \uparrow 3 \downarrow 2)$

Static allocation of all data areas by a compiler makes it impossible to implement recursion.

subject: Compiler Design
question:
Let $G_1 = (N, T, P, S_1)$ be a CFG where, $N=\{S_1, A, B\},T=\{a, b\}$ and $P$ is given by$$\begin{array}{l|l}
	S_1 \rightarrow a S_1 b &S_1 \rightarrow a B b \\
	S_1 \rightarrow a A b & B \rightarrow Bb\\
	A \rightarrow a A & B \rightarrow b\\
	A \rightarrow a
	\end{array}$$What is $L(G_1)$?

Use the grammar in Part(a) to give a CFG for $L_2 = \{a^ib^ja^kb^l \mid i, j, k, l \geq 1, i=j \text{ or } k=l\}$ by adding not more than $5$ production rules.
